pullRequest.title: Azure Tables Sync and Async Code Snippets
pullRequest.bodyText:
The goal of this ticket is to write out code samples that can be presented during the arch board meeting on the Tables SDK to demonstrate how our SDK handles the Champion Scenarios.
Code Snippets are written in both Sync and Async demonstrating the same champion scenarios.
The main purpose of the PR is to gather feedback on code snippets, they will not actually be released at this time.

nodes.bodyText:
This doesn't look correct. The artifact version should be 1.5.1.
Can your rebase your changes onto the latest master?

nodes.bodyText:
You have two different versions with the same dependencies, 12.7.0-beta.1 and 12.6.1.

There should only be one version.
The 12.7.0-beta.1 has the <scope>test</scope> which means it will only be used for testing, while 12.6.1 has <scope>compile</scope> which means it'll be used for shipping the product.

+package com.azure.data.tables;

nodes.bodyText: This should be using ClientLogger rather than System.err. or System.out. If you look at some of the azure-storage-blob client classes, you'll see examples of this.

These shouldn't be in the "src/main/java" folder. The "main" folder is for product code.
These should be in "src/samples/java". https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/java_documentation.html#code-samples
Since these are snippets dealing with the "TableServiceAsyncClient", this file can be called "TableServiceAsyncClientCodeSamples".
Here's an example.
https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/tree/master/sdk/eventhubs/azure-messaging-eventhubs/src/samples/java/com/azure/messaging/eventhubs
nit: unneeded spaces.
TableServiceAsyncClientBuilder should be called TableServiceClientBuilder. https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/java_design.html#service-clients
Additional space after //. For example: // Build service client

You'll need to format this document. Ctrl+Alt+L should reformat this.
The method names should be "insertEntity" rather than "InsertEntity"
Same wiht file name.
In general, you need to format your documents. There is inconsistent spacing.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,19 @@
+package com.azure.data.tables;

nodes.bodyText: The naming is incorrect https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/java_design.html#service-clients
Should there also be a way to get a single AzureTable by its name? e.g. @Nullable public AzureTable getTable(String name)?

Should there be a way to get a TableClient from a TableServiceClient? I'm imagining something like:
TableClient tableClient = tableServiceClient.queryTables("$selectString= TableName eq 'OfficeSupplies'")
                                            .first()
                                            .getClient();

(Or the same but with the hypothetical getTable("TableName") method I proposed in a previous comment.)
Should this return the AzureTable?

A TableClient already requires a tableName in order to create one, which implies to me that a given instance of TableClient only operates on the table that was specified when it was created. So if that's the case, we should avoid making the customer pass the table name again here.
Presumably you could just pass null as the tableEntityProperties too right? I suppose there isn't much use in inserting an empty row into the table, but if they want to do so, null should work too.

This is good. The service will update some properties on the entity such as the internal ETag value, so the customer should always save and reuse the return value, rather than the original tableEntity.
Actually that makes me think that it might be hard to explain that to customers. If they don't save this value and instead keep using the instance created on L57 to perform updates, that should fail because that instance doesn't have the ETag. This leads me to think that maybe our insertEntity call should just accept the row, partitionKey, and properties directly. That way the customer won't create a TableEntity instance that could get them into trouble later on.
Should there also be a way to get a single TableEntity by its row & partition key? e.g. @Nullable public TableEntity getEntity(String rowKey, String partitionKey)?
We should probably be consistent with the service and call these params rowKey and partitionKey everywhere.

Would it make sense to have a version of deleteEntity that just takes the row and partitionKey parameters? To avoid forcing the customer to get a TableEntity object just to delete it from the table (also if every API call costs the customer money, making a delete go from 2 to 1 REST calls is important).
Unlike the update/upsert operations, I don't think we need to provide an ETag in order to delete - I don't believe there is a potential concurrency problem there because we're not mutating properties on the row. If the service does require it then I guess there's nothing we can do here.

Should we also expose the top OData parameter? I'm of the mind we should either have 3 params, one for each OData parameter, or only a single query parameter (leaning towards the second option since we can make a QueryBuilder to help create query strings).
$select is just a comma+space separated list of fields you want to return - this isn't a valid $select string. Maybe "$select=Seller, Price"?
I think this is actually a filter string - just need to update the name (String filterString) and the prefix ($filter=)

Also not sure if it's required, but all the example I see for the OData syntax seem to have no whitespace around the equals sign, so maybe go through and remove it in any of your OData filters and selects just to be consistent.
Pretty much all of my comments from the sync snippets would apply here as well.
This value is unused.
This file shouldn't be in sdk/cosmos
nit: unnecessary empty lines. There are several places where you have 2 empty lines instead of one.

We don't align parameter names. If you edit your Settings, Code Style, Java, you can uncheck "Align parameter description" and "Align thrown exception description".
https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/code-style-java.html#javadoc
This file name should be TableServiceAsyncClientCodeSnippets.
Is tableEntityProperties mandatory? If not, would we want an overload that doesn't take this HashMap?
For consistency, I would probably make this method simply public AzureTable getTable(String name), and add a getClient() method on the AzureTable class.

I don't think this has value, since the only things we can get from an AzureTable are its name, which we already have (tableName) and a TableClient for the table, which this is. I would just remove this method.

I definitely see the value in insertEntity(TableEntity), and I -think- I could be convinced that we should have a convenience method that takes all the properties needed to create a TableEntity (i.e. insertEntity(row, partition, properties)), but I'm not clear if having a method that just takes row and partition without any properties, just to insert an empty entity in the table, is actually useful to the consumer.
I think I would start with having just a single insertEntity(TableEntity) method, and we can always add more later if UX study indicates it would be useful, but we can't take them away once they ship.
Should assign this to a result value AzureTable officeSuppliesTable = ...
Should we have a version of this method that takes an AzureTable object as well? Not sure myself, open for debate.
Should be private
This should be called buildClient for sync client and buildAsyncClient for async client.
Remove this line.
We should have a single builder that can build both sync and async clients.
Remove this line
Should this be assigned to something?
I don't think any storage packages are imported in this PR. So, this dependency can be removed.

nodes.bodyText: Should this return Mono<TableEntity> instead? Since insertEntity() is returning the inserted entity in the API above. Similarly, mergeEntity, insertOrReplaceEntity and insertOrReplaceEntity should all return the TableEntity that is resulting from these operations.
Same comment as async client - these methods should return TableEntity.
This should be public.
Builder should not have getter methods.
This should take the async client as param.

+    }

nodes.bodyText: Consider adding code snippets for merge(), insertOrMerge and  insertOrReplace operations too.
It would be easier to follow the code samples if you split the table service and table entity operations into separate methods like you have for the snippets for async client above.
Should we support exists(TableEntity) method to check the existence of a table entity to make it easier for the user?
It might be useful to add samples to show how the user can verify if a table exists.
Does the service not support updating a table?

nodes.bodyText: Is this dependency required?
nodes.diffHunk:

nodes.bodyText: Thanks for adding it to the code snippet. It might probably be something we should include in the public API itself but that's arch board discussion. For now, we can just keep it in the samples.
This can just be an overload of queryEntity() similar to what you have for deleteEntity().
We should also have *EntityWithResponse() methods for all APIs that return Mono<> but if the intent of this PR is to just show the code snippets, you can ignore this comment.
Also, should the name of the method be queryEntities() as it's returning a paged collection?
This doesn't have to be async as the table name is provided to the ctor.

In Reactor, void return types won't have onNext(). So, this message will have to be printed in onComplete() consumer. Update other samples too.
.subscribe(ignored -> {},
       error -> logger.error("...", error),
       () -> logger.info("Delete Entity Successful."));
The builder should also support either TokenCredential or AzureKeyCredential.

nodes.bodyText: These methods should return Mono<TableEntity> - the updated/upserted entity.
This returns a paged collection. So, you might have to check each tableEntity to find out if the one that you are testing for existence actually is in the returned collection.
Implementation types should not be used in public API.

HTTP service builders should have all these methods:
https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/java_design.html#java-service-client-builder-consistency

nodes.bodyText:
This and the one above are similar. Do we expect users to pass an entire map, or chain a bunch of addProperty calls?
I'd prefer addProperty (since it is used in your samples) and remove this one. Also, addProperties should be fluent, and return this like your query options class. Also, annotate class with @Fluent

nodes.bodyText: For samples, you can use System.out.println(). ClientLogger is used within our own SDK. Samples and code snippets are for other people to copy and paste into their own code, so we prefer they use System.out.
System.err.println` over ClientLogger

Highlight usage of the fluent model.
var queryOptions = new QueryOptions().setFilter("TableName eq OfficeSupplies");
No need for the intermediate local variable deleteEntityMono. Just return tableAsyncClient.delete....
unneeded space
